title: The Children of Propaganda
credits: Martin Kapel, Val Ginsburg, and Joseph Young reading ‘Why? Explaining the Holocaust’ by Peter Hayes

transcript.text: At this time in various countries,
people realised that awful things were happening in Germany
And they lobbied governments and they said:
‘We know you have a severe unemployment problem.’
Which pretty much all countries had.
‘We know you don’t want to add to it,
by bringing a lot of refugees into the country.
But will you save some of the children?’
And so in some countries, including Britain, said: yes.
And they organised what is called the Kindertransport.
‘Jews,’ said Hitler, unalterably seek to undermine
German’s fertility, military strength, and purity
in order to make them too weak to cast Jews off and out.
Thus, Jews were behind prostitution and venereal disease,
delusional notions like international law and human rights
and soft hearted ideas about the equality and brotherhood of people.
Like Nietzsche, Hitler thought Jews had introduced
the debilitating language of morality, ethics,
compassion, and empathy into the world.
Logically then, the Jew must be contained
and ultimately removed from the German sphere.
If Germany is to succeed in the struggle for living space
- Lebensraum, and survival.
Their idea of conscience was, he insisted
choosing his simile deliberately,
a blemish, like circumcision.
A supposedly unnatural alteration
of how human beings are created.
Hitler therefore promised in Mein Kampf
To rollback emancipation and drive Jews out
into their own world or abroad.
By expelling them first from German political life,
then from the nation’s cultural life, and finally,
from its economic life.
The party platform, the 25 point programme of 1920,
for instance, contained Point Four:
Calling for the denial of citizenship to Jews and their descendants
Point Five: Demanding their classification as resident aliens.
Point Six: excluding them from public office.
Point Eight: Blocking further immigration by Jews
and expelling all, who had entered the country
since the beginning of World War I.
The other atrocity took place in 1944.
And that was the so called Children’s Action.
In our ghetto, they had a number of children.
And they were our darlings. They were well looked after,
despite the hunger and the conditions.
I mean, for us, they were the symbol of our future.
We knew the Nazis are determined to exterminate
every single Jew in their power.
Orders came from Germany, that anybody
who was not employed, gainfully by work
should be eliminated.
On the 18th of March,
a detachment of SS and Ukrainian militia
marched into the ghetto, and they removed forcibly
all the children, all the disabled, all the sick people,
all the old people, anybody who couldn’t, wasn't fit for work.
They were killed the next day.
Val Ginsburg: Now I must point out that
whenever and wherever the Nazis occupied the country,
they made a special point of indoctrinating the population
spreading all sorts of vicious rumours
presenting the Jews as Communists, Bolsheviks,
they were presented as vermin to be exterminated.
And it seemed to work.
In fact 80% of the German killing machine
- of the Holocaust killing machine was non-German.
They knew that hunger is demoralising.
It reduces people to animal level.
And that’s what they wanted to do.
They wanted to dehumanise us, to demoralise us
and to isolate us completely from the non-Jewish population.
And then they could do away with us.
They told us to wear yellow Stars of David front and back,
to brand us as different from all the other people.
Iby Knill: I personally found that very  - I got very angry about it.
Because I couldn’t see why I should be any different to anybody else
Because none of my friends were wearing yellow stars
And I thought I would put them into an awkward situation,
if I stayed in friendships or relationships with them.
We were also taught that on public transport, we weren’t allowed to sit down.
In shops we were the last ones to be served. And I just decided
that I wasn’t going to use public transport under those circumstances.
I would rather walk to school and use a scarf to cover my yellow star.
So I seemed to spend most of my time queuing up in shops to get food
Because the rule was that people with yellow stars
should be the last ones to be served in shops.
So quite often by the time it became your turn,
there was hardly anything in the food shops nearby.
Also, our business had been what they called aryanised,
that the state took it over and put a non-Jewish person in charge
Although my parents had still to continue to work there.
I no longer have any reason to speak Slovak
I haven’t done so for the last 80 odd years
and the very few words in my head.
...of pageants. And I can remember standing on the little stage
in the village hall in ‘?’ with-
Sokol was this physical exercise movement.
1000s of us belonged. And the song I sang
was the song we used to sing as children
when we were going into the exercise class.
I couldn’t tell you clearly what it was. But I did sing one.
And now I can’t remember it.
Underneath Kriváň and Kriváň is one of the highest mountains in the Tatras.
If my geography still holds out. I never went to the Tatras.
And there’s a good reason for that. A) I don't think my father
would ever afford a - a skiing holiday day for the family.
And I went to a Jewish school and every winter,
our playground was turned into an ice rink.
So we went skating and mother was a keen swimmer
and we swam in the Danube.
Before the late 1920s, the Danube used to freeze over
and people used to skate on the Danube.
And I even brought my shoes with the skates screwed in,
with me to England.
I haven’t got them anymore, because I don't skate anymore.
It used to hang in our dining room come whatever it was,
it hung above our grand piano.
This room was between the room, which was our general room
in the flat and that general room contained-
we had a posh dining room, which also included our grand piano
with Judith hanging over the grand piano.
And we also had our cupboard cabinet,
which had our clothes in it.
And as well as that, my father had a very large desk,
with a telephone which was very unusual in those days.
And that was the desk at which he would do his writing.
And father and mother had twin beds pushed together
And the divan across the beds,
because Father used to have a nap after lunch,
because midday was when you had your main meal.
I very clearly remember the painting, because I was petrified of it.
And if I woke up and I was a bit afraid, I wanted to go in mother’s bed,
I had to go through here.
With a grand piano there and she hung up on this side of the grand piano
And she used to terrify me.
There she is. There’s Judith with a blooming head behind her skirt.
My sister and I learned piano, my brother learned violin.
Mother played the piano.
And father was very interested in opera and music.
So there was music in the house.
My brother used to make little crystal sets,
which we had a little thing,
you used to put your little pin in, and it would then make crackling noises.
And we used to listen eventually, to Mr. Hitler shouting.
And I remember that very distinctly.
Radios, I suppose were quite novel things in those days.
And father used to go into that room to listen to broadcasts.
And I can remember broadcasts of Hitler,
because he used to always shout when he was speaking.
I can’t remember the contents because I think as a young child,
it wasn’t of interest to me. We had a communal room
in which my brother sister and I slept.
We had our dining table, and father had his large desk.
And we had a telephone on the desk. So that was it.
There. The next door, we had this other in between room
where we had a grand piano and we had this fantastic painting
of Judith and Helofernes.
It used to frighten me a bit.
So I - my father was a banker -
I think most of the memory is just that it was there
above the piano. And that was all.
And that picture now hangs in my daughter’s house,
because I haven’t got room for picture, which is 4.6 ft by 4ft.
It was only after the war, when I started doing research on it,
but it was hidden during the war.
And eventually, through my eldest cousin, Igot to find out
that it had been hidden by, at my grandmother’s farm,
by some peasants or something.
And it ended up in my uncle’s house, after he had returned from Russia,
with the Czechoslovak army contingent,
which was within the Russian army at the time,
and he was a doctor, and it ended up in his house.
And then in the 1990s, after my uncle had died,
my sister and I went to where my uncle lived.
And it was called Senec. And we told his second wife
because his first wife had been murdered in Auschwitz with his daughter.
And this other lady had no idea that this painting actually belonged to
my side of the family and not to her.
So she was quite amenable for us to retrieve it.
And we brought it over to England.
My sister didn’t want to have this large painting.
But there were two other paintings two some very much smaller ones.
And she was going to have one and my brother could have had the other.
But my brother didn’t want any of things.
He didn’t want anything to do with the Holocaust anymore at that stage.
Can you see her, I can’t see her anymore?
Oh, well come up a bit further then.
Yes, let me just see if I can see her.
I can see her clearly enough.
Now I can see her better
And be able to see her better still.
Yes, I can see her now.
Hello, Judith. Haven’t seen you for a bit.
I think it was painted in the 18th century for Ludwig the II
Or Ludwig the mad or whatever he was called.
And it’s 4ft6 by 4ft.
It’s got a beautiful frame. But Judith herself has fantastic little plaits,
a beautiful gown and a bejewelled sword,
which she’s holding in her left hand and with her right hand,
Just behind her skirt, you can see the head of Holofernes.
It is sort of tastefully hidden, but obviously,
She has cut off his head and killed him.
And there she is standing, looking straight ahead of herself
When the picture came, because it’s so large,
she didn’t really have any room for it.
So she said would I like it in my house.
So I was very happy to have whatever came really,
because it’s just about the only heirloom that we've got.
It’s very striking. Whenever we had anyone coming into our house
for the first time, they would always notice the picture.
And we would always have a conversation about the story behind it
And where it had come from.
So it’s now in the stairwell on the third floor of our townhouse.
It was really quite difficult to get up there,
one of my sons stood on the bannister.
It’s sort of trying to manoeuvre this very heavy, large picture.
So I’ve no idea how we'll ever get it down again, really?
I see it every day when I come up and downstairs from my bedroom.
But yes, it’s sort of part of my life, now, I suppose.
It’s you know, the one very large, concrete thing
that has come from my mother’s home.
So yes, it’s got place, close to my heart, really.
It’s the only thing really, that's come.
And is it very coincidental that I’m called Judith?
It’s a guilt frame. And it's plaster work.
Decorated with flowers and bunches of grapes and leaves and things
They are quite intricate, but it’s been quite damaged.
And to get it restored the frame and the picture
It would have been very expensive.
But we were also advised that actually that might
change the nature of it, so we decided that we would leave it as it is.
And I think it’s more evocative, really, that it is damaged.
I think it just shows us a lot of history to the painting,
not just about the painting when it was painted,
but the the life of the painting, that it’s travelled.
You know, hundreds of miles.
It’s been in hiding.
I think it just adds to the story of the painting.
So I like it as it is

title: Wires and Fences
credits: Ibi Ginsburg, John Chillag, Eugene Black, Arek Hersh and families; and Kath Shackleton, Fettle Animation & BBC.

transcript.text: And as walked,
oh we walked probably a mile or so
we passed on our right hand side
these huge big camps
and they were surrounded by barbed wire.
But real big, efficient wires.
And between the two wires,
there was a huge, big ditch.
And the outside wire was electrified.
And there was a constant humming from it.
That power was so strong,
that you could smell it.
It had a scorching smell
and every so often,
there were lookout towers where an SS was standing
with guards, with a machine gun.
Just in case somebody goes to the wire,
because if you went near that wire,
half a yard
you were just sucked in
- you were electrocuted.
Each of these sort of ‘better’ groups were sort of
identifiable in one way or another.
There was a gypsy camp
and a Czech camp and so on.
Dogs in between and watch towers
with machine guns trained on us
so there wasn’t really any escape from there.
If the guard (?) didn’t get you, the dogs did,
if the dogs didn’t - then the watch tower.
A number of people had, so to say, escaped.
They walked straight into the electric barbed wire.
It was an escape
- of suicide.
And some people had done that.
And a horrible smell was all over the camp
- terrible.
The time I spent in Ausschwitz and Birkenau
That was there, continuously,
24 hours a day.
The other people, around 150 of them,stood outside.
The two SS men still stood in front of the gate.
And as I walked in the church I- my thoughts were:
Elderly people, children, and so on.
The omen was not very good,
because I’ve seen what Germans do with people like that.
And then I thought to myself, whatever happens
to my mother and brother and sister, I’m with a family.
And it was very traumatic for me
Because I didn’t want to be parted from
my mother and my brothers and sisters
And then we were marched off
and that’s the last time I'd see-
my mother and brothers and sister.
They decided to liquidate the Ghetto.
They told us to assemble in the square
and they marched us to the church.
It was a fairly small church and they pushed in
4000 people at that church, without water,
without any food, without any toilet facilities.
Imagine 4000 People in a place
without any toilet facilities.
They told us to come out from the church
and there were two SS officers
And they look you over and asked you your profession.
I told them I was a tailor.
I couldn’t thread a needle,
but I thought: You know, if I can do something,
They’ll take me.
They told me to go with my mother,
and our family, back into the church.
Anyway, it was a very hot day,
I wanted to go for some water, to the gate.
And when I did, the SS men shouted at me, the officer:
‘What’s your profession?'
I told him, I was a tailor, once again, a tailor.
He told me to run now, join the 150 people.
And we were taken to Lodz Ghetto.
And all the 3000 - how many? - were taking to Chelmno.
And they were gassed.
And then burried in mass graves.
Well, you know you’re a survivor because you're there
Well obviously my contemporaries who committed these atrocities are dreadful
but I’m concerned that...
sometimes think what I would have been if I hadn’t been Jewish
Would I have been a Nazi?
And I probably would
You know, it’s very difficult for a 12, 13, 14 year-old
to resist the temptations the Nazis offered for kids of that age
Uniforms, campfires, learning to shoot rifles
Things like that as they had in the Hitler Youth
And, it’s very very difficult for a kid of that age to resist that temptation
And not be part of the crowd

title: Enosh
credits: Rudi Leavor and family; and Stephen Muir

transcript.text: Enosh
When people gradually started to learn that I was researching Jewish music
A lot of people said: ‘Oh, you must speak to Rudi Leavor.’
When I first met Rudi, which was at the Bradford synagogue,
I asked him what his story was, as it were.
He talked about his youth, and then the Nazi occupation, etc.
And how he’d come to England. And he talked a little bit about
how he’d been a singer in the synagogue, most of his life,
eventually became the Kantor the Bradford synagogue.
He played violin, as a child,
but had never had any kind of formal theoretical,
university level type of education in music.
In fact, he was a dentist, very good dentist, I believe.
But he kept that music going. And then in the nine- in the 70s,
He composed Enosh.
Not- I don’t know if it was exactly out of the blue,
but it seems to be out of the blue.
He told me about this in a very matter of fact, way.
‘Oh, yeah. And then in the 70s I,’
‘I composed this opera’ as he called it.
Not quite accurate, but that doesn’t matter.
I composed his opera called Enosh.
I said: ‘Oh yeah, what’s that?'
And he said: ‘Oh it’s a it's a thing for chorus and full orchestra solos.
[inaudible]
Rudy was very musically knowledgeable,
from a sort of very advanced amateur level.
He knew his opera very well.
He was an admirer of Bach, and Mozart, Beethoven,
you know the sorts of classic-
My father played the piano, Chopin, Schubert, Beethoven,
and my mother sang
As a child or his father had some LPs, I think,
that they listened to, I think one of them was
the Berlioz L’enfance du Christ,
which remained a very dear piece to him throughout his life
and was performed in the same concept as-
well an extract from it was was performed in same concert as Enosh.
And so, he was steeped in a sort of Western classical music tradition,
as well as a synagogue music tradition,
some of which is very similar to that western classical tradition,
but some of it some of which is not.
And it’s very almost Islamic in nature, or Arabic, certainly, in its influences.
And so what I think he was trying to achieve was to meld
his knowledge of classical music with that synagogue tradition.
Enosh
It’s like an oratoria, really.
Rudi, didn’t just leave the tunes as they were.
He sort of intervened musically, he changed aspects of some of the
what we might call hymns, in the synagogue.
The classic one is Enosh ‘Mankind’
which is sung on Yom Kippur. It’s very serious.
It’s sort of the end of a long process of
praying and singing towards the end of a fast.
It’s very well known in the Jewish world.
But he changed aspects of harmony,
sort of played around with the rhythm a little bit.
You’ll hear it start and you'll think ‘Oh, yes that's Enosh.'
And then you’ll hear something a bit different.
And you’ll think ‘Oh, that's not quite what I remember.'
And it makes you think more about the music
rather than just hearing a familiar tune.
What he was trying to do is to is to sort of feed into a tradition,
or two traditions, the Jewish and the Western classical music.
But to disrupt it a little bit and draw our attention to certain things.
And the soloists music is in a much more modern idiom.
It’s beautifully written actually.
The story is of the Jewish people, essentially.
It starts with the people of Israel, being happy
to have arrived in the Promised Land.
And then it becomes gradually more serious
as they’re overtaken by various events throughout history.
Whilst it’s never upfront, explicitly expressed,
you can identify particular historical things,
and eventually coming to the Holocaust.
And there’s a moment where there's obvious references to Hitler
without naming him and to the horrors that
were perpetrated upon the Jewish people.
And then after that, there is a short epilogue, I guess
whereby there is a sort of sign of hope for the future,
I would say a qualified hope, not a
not an a sort of an ecstatic, uncontrolled hope.
But there is a sort of root space for reflection and optimism.
He left Germany quite early on in his childhood.
And he left before the worst of the atrocities otherwise,
one might assume, sadly, that he wouldn’t have survived.
So thank God, he did leave.
So he never spoke to me about that individually,
but I knew the history, more or less.
We went by train, ship, train, and then train.
I liked travelling, the excitement,
I think, whilst again, he never articulated it precisely.
I think that that was quite a powerful
personal, I wouldn’t say reconciliation with,
but engagement with an expression of that trauma that survivors suffer.
I think certainly the power of the music that he wrote,
that comes from somewhere.
I think he was working through a number
of historical, emotional aspects
From Hamburg to Bremer Hafen we had the compartment to ourselves.
Then the customs officer came around,
he asked my father to go to another compartment.
We stopped at a station. When we set off I said:
‘Where’s daddy?'
My mother was just as frightened. But she said: ‘He’ll be along.'
They had asked him questions and body searched him.
He did talk about his, his escape,
for want of a better word, the music and the narrative in the text
works through some of that idea of escape,
and finding a better life somewhere.
And then, the risk of it all happening again,
and eventual partial catharsis.
So there was a tender to take us on the ship to the quay side.
We went to the station. It seemed very dark.
It was November. So it got dark early.
It was raining, there were gas lights,
and the train puffed a lot of steam.
That was our entry to England.
And the new and better life.
One could tell when he felt something very deeply.
He’s very sincere man. A very gentle man.
I would say. One of my main impulses behind doing it was
Yes, there’s a self interest in terms of the research
and the potential academic outcomes and things like that.
But actually, the most important thing for me was to do it,
to get it done for Rudi.
Because he kept saying to me, I’m on a limited timescale here.
He knew that he wouldn’t be surviving another 20 years or something
and that it needed to be done there and then.
And so, within the kind of confines of what I could do,
I wanted to do it for him primarily.
